summary_llm:
The story begins with Pip, an orphan, introducing himself and his deceased family members through their tombstones in a bleak churchyard on the marsh country. While visiting the graves, a fearful, coarse-looking man with an iron on his leg emerges and threatens to kill Pip. The man demands Pip's name, where he lives, a file, and food ("wittles") by the next morning at the old Battery. He warns Pip not to tell anyone, claiming a "young man" is with him who would cut out Pip's heart and liver if he failed or spoke of their meeting. Terrified, Pip promises to steal the items.

Pip lives with his much older, bad-tempered sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, who raised him "by hand" (implying physical abuse), and her kind, mild-mannered husband, Joe Gargery, the blacksmith. Mrs. Joe is physically and verbally abusive to both Pip and Joe. Pip, burdened by his promise, steals bread, cheese, mincemeat, brandy, a meat bone, and a pork pie from the pantry, and a file from Joe's forge.

The next morning, in a thick mist, Pip heads to the Battery. He first encounters another man, also wearing an iron, whom he mistakenly thinks is the first man. This "young man" jumps up, swings at Pip, and then stumbles away. Pip soon finds the first convict, Magwitch, who is shivering and hungry. Pip gives him the stolen items, which Magwitch devours. Magwitch questions Pip about being alone, then, upon hearing Pip saw the "young man," becomes agitated and furiously files at his leg iron. Pip, frightened, slips away.

Later that day, Christmas, soldiers arrive at Joe's house, requesting Joe to mend a pair of handcuffs. The sergeant mentions they are hunting two escaped convicts on the marshes. Joe repairs the handcuffs. Pip, Joe, Mr. Wopsle (the church clerk), and Uncle Pumblechook (Mrs. Joe's uncle, a cornchandler) gather for Christmas dinner. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe constantly lecture Pip on gratitude and his low status. Mrs. Joe serves brandy, which Pip has refilled with tar-water. Pumblechook drinks it and has a violent reaction, gasping "Tar!" Pip is horrified, thinking he has poisoned him. Later, as Mrs. Joe prepares to serve a pork pie, Pip realizes it's the one he stole and, in terror, runs, only to be met at the door by the soldiers. He realizes the handcuffs are not for him.

Pip, Joe, Mr. Wopsle, and the soldiers go to the marshes. They hear shouts and discover the two convicts fighting in a ditch. Pip's convict, Magwitch, claims he captured the other, Compeyson, who had previously tried to murder him. Compeyson, bruised, accuses Magwitch of attempted murder. Magwitch is re-manacled and taken to a prison-ship (Hulk). Before being taken, Magwitch confesses to stealing food from the blacksmith's. Joe, touched by Magwitch's misery, tells him he's welcome to the food, revealing his profound kindness.

Pip is freed from suspicion but burdened by guilt. He struggles with telling Joe the truth, fearing to lose his friend's confidence. Joe, meanwhile, tells the curious villagers that the convict broke in through the chimney. Mrs. Joe is seriously injured and becomes an invalid, only able to communicate by writing on a slate. Biddy, Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's granddaughter, comes to live with them and becomes Mrs. Joe's caregiver, translating her slate writings. Biddy realizes Mrs. Joe's cryptic "T" drawing signifies Orlick, Joe's journeyman, by his hammer. Mrs. Joe, to Pip's surprise, treats Orlick with a strange "humble propitiation."

Pip's apprenticeship continues, marked by annual visits to Miss Havisham. He feels ashamed of his common life and secretly desires to become a gentleman for Estella. Biddy, who has become refined and intelligent, tries to dissuade him, suggesting he is happier as he is. Pip, impatient, accuses her of envy. One day, Miss Havisham tells Pip his apprenticeship to Joe should begin immediately. Miss Havisham then provides 25 guineas for Pip's apprenticeship, implying no further favors. Joe, who accompanies Pip, refuses any personal compensation, emphasizing his friendship with Pip. Pumblechook, however, claims credit for Pip's good fortune. Pip is formally bound to Joe.

Pip becomes ashamed of his home and Joe, feeling his "great expectations" separate him. He confides in Biddy, who correctly identifies his desire to impress Estella as the root of his discontent. Estella, however, is being educated abroad.

Years later, while Pip is listening to Mr. Wopsle read a murder trial in a pub, Mr. Jaggers, a London lawyer, enters. Jaggers, whom Pip recognizes as the man from Miss Havisham's, questions Wopsle's legal understanding. Jaggers then announces that Pip has "great expectations" and will come into a "handsome property," to be brought up as a gentleman. He reveals he is Pip's guardian, and Pip is to receive a substantial annual income until the anonymous benefactor reveals themselves. Pip is strictly forbidden from inquiring about his patron. Jaggers recommends Mr. Matthew Pocket (Miss Havisham's cousin) as Pip's tutor. Pip assumes Miss Havisham is his benefactor. Joe, overwhelmed, emotionally refuses any money for Pip's lost services, declaring their enduring friendship. Pip leaves for London, feeling both excitement and a deep sense of separation from Joe and his past.

In London, Pip finds Barnard's Inn dingy and disappointing. He meets Herbert Pocket, who he recognizes as the "pale young gentleman" he fought in Miss Havisham's garden. They become close friends. Herbert reveals Miss Havisham's tragic story: she was jilted on her wedding day by a man named Compeyson, who conspired with her half-brother Arthur. This led her to stop all clocks and live in eternal decay. Estella is Miss Havisham's adopted daughter, raised to break men's hearts. Herbert, a hopeful but financially struggling capitalist, becomes Pip's confidant and friend.

Pip and Herbert accumulate debts. Pip learns from Wemmick, Jaggers's clerk, about Jaggers's dual personality: a ruthless lawyer in the city and a kind, eccentric man at his "Castle" home in Walworth, where he cares for his deaf "Aged Parent" and has a fiancée, Miss Skiffins. Wemmick advises Pip to keep his office and private lives separate.

Pip receives a letter from Trabb & Co. announcing Mrs. Joe's death. He returns home for the funeral. He is deeply moved by the quiet ceremony and feels remorse for his ingratitude to Joe and Biddy. Pumblechook, still self-important, tries to claim credit for Pip's fortunes. Pip learns from Biddy that his sister, in her last conscious moments, spoke "Joe," "Pardon," and "Pip." He also learns that Orlick was the one who attacked Mrs. Joe, using Magwitch's filed-off leg-iron, and is now in jail. Biddy reveals she is leaving to become a schoolmistress and will care for Joe.

Later, Pip is disturbed to learn from Mr. Wopsle that Compeyson was seen behind him at the theatre. Pip writes to Wemmick, communicating this danger.

At a dinner at Jaggers's house, Pip, Herbert, Startop, and Drummle are present. Jaggers reveals that Drummle is pursuing Estella. Jaggers compels his housekeeper, Molly, to show her scarred wrists. Pip realizes Molly is Estella's mother, a woman acquitted of murder, defended by Jaggers. Jaggers subtly implies he orchestrated Estella's adoption to save her from a life of crime, given her background.

Pip learns Estella is engaged to Drummle. He confronts her, confessing his love and pleading with her not to marry Drummle, a "brute." Estella coldly states she has "no heart" and will marry Drummle to change her life. She reminds Pip that she is what Miss Havisham made her. Pip leaves Satis House, devastated. He then receives a cryptic note from Wemmick: "DON'T GO HOME."

Pip, following Wemmick's warning, stays at a hotel. He learns from Wemmick that Provis's chambers are being watched by Compeyson, who is in London. Herbert, alerted by Pip's note, moves Provis to a secluded lodging on Mill Pond Bank under the alias Mr. Campbell, with Herbert's fiancée Clara and her father, Mr. Barley. Wemmick advises Pip to obtain passports and prepare for Provis's escape from England.

Pip, receiving a mysterious anonymous note to meet at the sluice-house for information about "your uncle Provis," goes to the marshes. He is ambushed by Orlick, who ties him up and reveals he was the lurker on Pip's stairs and the one who attacked Mrs. Joe, blaming Pip for his misfortunes. Orlick declares his intention to kill Pip and dispose of his body in the limekiln. Just as Orlick is about to strike, Herbert and Startop, guided by Trabb's Boy (who had found Pip's dropped letter), burst in and save Pip.

Pip, Herbert, and Startop then put their plan for Magwitch's escape into action. They row Magwitch down the Thames. They are intercepted by a four-oared galley carrying Custom House officers and Compeyson, who has been working with them. In the ensuing struggle, Magwitch and Compeyson both fall overboard. Magwitch is rescued but severely injured. Compeyson is not found. Magwitch is manacled and taken back to London for trial. Pip's repugnance for Magwitch vanishes, replaced by affection and loyalty.

Magwitch is tried and found guilty, sentenced to death. Pip visits him daily in the infirmary, tending to him and writing petitions. As Magwitch is dying, Pip reveals to him that his child (Estella) is alive, beautiful, a lady, and that Pip loves her. Magwitch, with a last smile, raises Pip's hand to his lips and dies peacefully. Pip prays, "O Lord, be merciful to him a sinner!"

Pip falls ill with a fever and is arrested for debt. He is nursed back to health by Joe, who has come to London and paid off Pip's debts. Pip, realizing his ingratitude and Joe's unwavering love, is humbled. He learns that Miss Havisham has died, leaving most of her property to Estella, but also four thousand pounds to Mr. Matthew Pocket due to Pip's account of his goodness.

Pip returns to the forge, intending to propose to Biddy and work with Joe. However, he finds Joe and Biddy are married. He gives them his blessing and resolves to leave England to work off his debts and find his own way. He liquidates his remaining assets, pays his creditors, and joins Herbert in Cairo, becoming a clerk and eventually a partner in Clarriker and Co.

Eleven years later, Pip returns to his native village. He finds Joe and Biddy have a child named Pip. He revisits the site of Satis House, now demolished except for the garden wall, and finds Estella there. She is greatly changed, her beauty softened by suffering. She reveals she had an unhappy marriage with Drummle (implied), who has since died. She tells Pip that suffering has taught her to understand his heart. They acknowledge their enduring friendship, and Pip sees "no shadow of another parting from her."

summary_llm:
This detailed summary is based solely on the provided text, without any external knowledge or interpretation.

**Act I**

**Scene I: Elsinore. A Platform Before the Castle. Night.**
The play opens on a cold night at the castle platform in Elsinore, Denmark. Bernardo relieves Francisco from his guard duty. Bernardo, joined by Horatio and Marcellus, discusses a strange apparition they have witnessed on the previous two nights. Horatio, a scholar, is skeptical and believes it is "but our fantasy," but Marcellus has entreated him to watch with them. The Ghost appears, resembling the recently deceased King Hamlet, clad in the same armor he wore when he combated Norway. Horatio, struck with fear and wonder, attempts to speak to the Ghost, charging it to reveal its purpose, but it silently stalks away. Horatio, now convinced, remarks on its striking resemblance to the late king and believes its appearance "bodes some strange eruption to our state," recalling similar ominous signs before Julius Caesar's fall in Rome. The Ghost reappears. Horatio again implores it to speak, asking if it has a message, a good deed to be done for its ease, knowledge of the country's fate, or hidden treasure. Before it can speak, the cock crows, startling the Ghost, and it vanishes. Horatio explains that spirits retreat at the cock's crow. He then suggests they inform young Hamlet, the dead King's son, believing the spirit, though dumb to them, will speak to him. They agree to share what they have witnessed with Hamlet.

**Scene II: A Room of State in the Palace.**
The current King, Claudius, addresses his court. He acknowledges his dear brother King Hamlet's death but declares that, with the court's approval, he has married his "sometime sister, now our queen," Gertrude. Laertes, son of Polonius, requests permission to return to France, having come to Denmark for Claudius's coronation. Polonius confirms he has reluctantly granted his son leave, and the King also gives his blessing. The King then addresses Hamlet, noting his continued melancholic demeanor. Hamlet, in an aside, expresses his displeasure with the new King. The Queen urges Hamlet to cast off his dark mourning and accept the commonality of death. Hamlet asserts his grief is genuine, beyond mere outward show. The King admonishes Hamlet for his "unmanly grief" and "impious stubbornness," reminding him he is "most immediate to our throne" and his "son." The Queen asks Hamlet to stay in Denmark and not return to Wittenberg. Hamlet agrees to obey his mother. Pleased, the King declares a celebration with cannon fire.

Once the court exits, Hamlet expresses profound despair and suicidal thoughts, wishing his "solid flesh would melt." He laments his mother's hasty marriage to his uncle, Claudius, less than two months after his father's death. He contrasts his noble father ("Hyperion") with Claudius ("a satyr") and expresses disgust at his mother's swift transition from deep mourning to remarriage, calling her "Frailty." He forces himself to remain silent about his inner turmoil.

Horatio, Bernardo, and Marcellus enter. Hamlet, initially joyful to see Horatio, questions why he has returned from Wittenberg, cynically suggesting it was for his mother's wedding rather than his father's funeral, noting how "the funeral bak'd meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables." Horatio then reveals the purpose of their visit: they saw his father's ghost. Hamlet interrogates them intensely about the Ghost's appearance, its armor, pale face, and grizzled beard. Convinced by their consistent account, Hamlet resolves to join their watch tonight, determined to speak to the apparition. He extracts a solemn promise from them not to reveal what they have seen. Alone again, Hamlet suspects "foul play" and eagerly awaits the night.

**Scene III: A Room in Polonius's House.**
Laertes is preparing to depart for France. He warns his sister, Ophelia, against Hamlet's affections, dismissing them as a fleeting "toy in blood" and not genuine or lasting. He emphasizes that Hamlet, as a prince, cannot choose his own path, as his choice impacts the entire state. Laertes cautions Ophelia to guard her honor. Ophelia promises to heed his advice but playfully warns him not to be a hypocrite, preaching a moral path while indulging in "the primrose path of dalliance" himself.

Polonius enters, hurrying Laertes to his ship. He then offers his son a lengthy list of precepts for conduct, including: "Give thy thoughts no tongue," "Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar," "Grapple them to thy soul with hooks of steel" for true friends, avoid quarrels, listen more than you speak, dress well but not ostentatiously, and "Neither a borrower nor a lender be." Most importantly, he advises, "To thine ownself be true; And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man." Laertes departs.

Polonius then questions Ophelia about what Laertes told her. Ophelia reveals it was about Lord Hamlet. Polonius, concerned, states he has heard Hamlet has been spending private time with her and she has been receptive. He chastises her for her naiveté, calling her a "green girl, Unsifted in such perilous circumstance," and questions if she believes Hamlet's declarations of affection. Ophelia admits she doesn't know what to think. Polonius dismisses Hamlet's "honourable fashion" and "holy vows" as "springes to catch woodcocks" (traps for the gullible) and strictly forbids Ophelia from having any further contact or conversation with Hamlet. Ophelia promises to obey.

**Scene IV: The Platform. Night.**
Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus are on watch. The cold air bites "shrewdly." They hear trumpets and cannon fire, signifying the King's late-night revelry. Hamlet criticizes this custom, calling it "More honour'd in the breach than the observance." The Ghost appears. Hamlet addresses it directly, calling it "Hamlet, King, father: Royal Dane," and demands to know why his spirit is unrestrained, revisiting the earth in complete steel. The Ghost beckons Hamlet to follow it alone. Horatio and Marcellus try to restrain Hamlet, fearing it will lead him to madness or harm. Hamlet, disregarding their warnings and threats, breaks free and follows the Ghost, declaring he does not value his life or fear for his immortal soul.

**Scene V: A More Remote Part of the Platform. Night.**
The Ghost leads Hamlet to a secluded area. Hamlet demands it speak. The Ghost reveals itself to be the spirit of Hamlet's father, doomed to walk the night and "fast in fires" during the day until his earthly "foul crimes" are purged. It charges Hamlet to "Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder." Hamlet is shocked to hear of murder. The Ghost explains that the official story – that a serpent stung him while he slept in his orchard – is a lie. He reveals that "The serpent that did sting thy father's life Now wears his crown," explicitly naming Claudius as the murderer. The Ghost details how Claudius, "that incestuous, that adulterate beast," seduced Queen Gertrude with "witchcraft of his wit" and "traitorous gifts." He describes how Claudius poured "juice of cursed hebenon" into his ears while he slept, causing a swift, agonizing death that ravaged his body with a "leperous distilment." Thus, King Hamlet was "Of life, of crown, of queen, at once despatch'd," dying without confession or last rites, with "all my imperfections on my head." The Ghost commands Hamlet to take revenge but warns him not to "taint thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive Against thy mother aught: leave her to Heaven," and to "those thorns that in her bosom lodge, To prick and sting her." The Ghost then bids farewell, urging Hamlet to "remember me," and vanishes as dawn approaches.

Hamlet, overwhelmed, vows to erase all other memories and live only for the Ghost's command of revenge. Horatio and Marcellus arrive, searching for Hamlet. Hamlet, agitated, makes cryptic and wild statements, leading them to believe he is disoriented. He extracts a solemn oath from them on his sword, reinforced by the Ghost's voice from beneath the stage, never to reveal what they have seen. Hamlet further warns them that he may "put an antick disposition on" (feign madness) in the future, and they must not give any sign of knowing his secret. He laments, "The time is out of joint;--O cursèd spite, That ever I was born to set it right!" They exit together.

**Act II**

**Scene I: A Room in Polonius's House.**
Ophelia, deeply distressed, tells her father Polonius about a terrifying encounter with Hamlet. She describes Hamlet entering her room with his clothes disheveled, pale, knees knocking, and a piteous look. He seized her by the wrist, stared intently at her face for a long time, then shook her arm, waved his head three times, sighed profoundly, and left without looking at her, keeping his eyes fixed on her until he was out of sight. Polonius, without hesitation, concludes that Hamlet is "Mad for thy love." Ophelia confirms that, following Polonius's command, she had "repel[led] his letters, and denied His access to me." Polonius now believes his instruction caused Hamlet's madness and determines to inform the King.

**Scene II: A Room in the Castle.**
King Claudius and Queen Gertrude welcome Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, Hamlet's childhood friends, to the court. They express concern over Hamlet's "transformation" and "lunacy" since his father's death, and ask the friends to spend time with him, "draw him on to pleasures," and discover the cause of his affliction. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern readily agree. Polonius enters, announcing he has discovered "The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy." In a long-winded speech, he declares Hamlet is mad. He then presents a love letter from Hamlet to Ophelia, expressing his love, despite poor poetic skill. Polonius explains that upon observing Hamlet's "hot love" for Ophelia, he strictly commanded his daughter to reject Hamlet's advances and deny him access. He attributes Hamlet's subsequent sadness, weakness, and eventual "madness" directly to this rejection. The King and Queen, though somewhat skeptical, agree to Polonius's plan to observe Hamlet's interaction with Ophelia, while they hide.

Hamlet enters, reading a book, and Polonius approaches him. Hamlet, feigning madness, calls Polonius a "fishmonger" and makes cryptic remarks about honesty and Ophelia, warning Polonius not to let her "walk i'the sun." Polonius, aside, notes, "Though this be madness, yet there's method in it." Hamlet continues his "mad" discourse, reading "slanders" from his book that describe old men unflatteringly, which Polonius recognizes as hitting too close to home. Hamlet dismisses Polonius curtly.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern enter. Hamlet greets them warmly but quickly discerns that they were "sent for" by the King and Queen to spy on him. They confess this. Hamlet then articulates his profound melancholy: he has "lost all my mirth," finding the world a "steril promontory" and man, despite his noble qualities, merely a "quintessence of dust," delighting neither him nor women. Rosencrantz reveals that a company of players is coming to court, which Hamlet greets with enthusiasm. He learns they are "the tragedians of the city" and are traveling due to new competition and a decline in public favor, possibly linked to Claudius's new reign.

Polonius re-enters to announce the players. Hamlet continues to mock Polonius with nonsensical wordplay and quotes from the story of Jephthah, implying a connection to Polonius's daughter. The Players enter, and Hamlet warmly welcomes them. He asks the First Player to recite a passionate speech, specifically Æneas's account of Priam's slaughter from a play he admired. The First Player delivers the speech with such emotion that Polonius is moved to tears.

After the Players depart, Hamlet, alone, reflects on his own inaction. He is struck by the player's ability to conjure such profound emotion for a fictional character (Hecuba) while he, Hamlet, with a real, urgent motive for revenge, remains paralyzed and cannot act. He berates himself as a "rogue and peasant slave," a "dull and muddy-mettled rascal," and a coward. He devises a plan: he will have the players perform a play, "something like the murder of my father," before his uncle. He will "observe his looks; I'll tent him to the quick: if he do blench, I know my course." He acknowledges the Ghost he saw might be the Devil, seeking to "Abuses me to damn me," so he needs concrete proof. He concludes, "The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king."

**Act III**

**Scene I: A Room in the Castle.**
The King and Queen question Rosencrantz and Guildenstern about Hamlet's behavior. They report that Hamlet confesses to feeling distracted but will not reveal the cause, maintaining a "crafty madness." They mention his excitement about the players and his invitation for the King and Queen to attend a play that night. The King and Queen, pleased by this development, encourage the friends to further engage Hamlet. The King then asks the Queen to leave, as he and Polonius have arranged for Ophelia to "affront" (confront) Hamlet while they secretly observe, hoping to determine if his madness stems from love. The Queen expresses her hope that Ophelia's beauty will restore Hamlet to sanity. Polonius instructs Ophelia to read a book to "colour Your loneliness" and reflects, aside, on how people often disguise evil with a "devotion's visage." The King, also aside, expresses guilt, feeling "how smart A lash that speech doth give my conscience!" They hide as Hamlet enters.

Hamlet delivers his famous soliloquy, "To be, or not to be," contemplating suicide as an escape from life's suffering, but deterred by the unknown terrors of the afterlife – "The undiscovered country, from whose bourn No traveller returns." He concludes that this fear of what comes after death "does make cowards of us all," causing great enterprises to falter and "lose the name of action."

Ophelia re-enters. Hamlet greets her, asking her to remember his sins in her prayers. Ophelia attempts to return "remembrances" (gifts) he once gave her. Hamlet denies ever having given them and, in an increasingly harsh and erratic manner, questions her honesty and beauty. He claims he never loved her and tells her to "Get thee to a nunnery," warning her against being a "breeder of sinners." He calls himself proud, revengeful, and ambitious, and condemns all men as "arrant knaves." He asks where her father is, and upon learning he is home, demands the doors be shut upon him so he can only "play the fool" in his own house. He continues his tirade, railing against marriage and women's vanity and deceit, declaring "I'll no more of't; it hath made me mad," and that there will be no more marriages, "all but one" (implying the King) shall live, the rest remain unmarried. Hamlet exits, still commanding, "To a nunnery, go."

Ophelia, heartbroken, laments the "noble mind... o'erthrown," mourning Hamlet's apparent descent into madness. The King and Polonius emerge from hiding. The King concludes Hamlet's distress is not caused by love but by some deeper, underlying melancholy, and proposes sending Hamlet to England to demand "neglected tribute," hoping travel will cure him. Polonius, still convinced Hamlet's madness is rooted in rejected love, suggests one last attempt: the Queen should speak with Hamlet after the play, and he (Polonius) will again hide and eavesdrop. If this fails, then Hamlet can be sent to England. The King agrees, stating, "Madness in great ones must not unwatch'd go."

**Scene II: A Room in the Castle.**
Hamlet instructs a Player on proper acting technique, emphasizing naturalness, temperance, and holding "the mirror up to nature," and criticizing overacting and improvised clowning. Horatio enters, and Hamlet praises him for his steady character. Hamlet confides in Horatio, revealing that a scene in the upcoming play mirrors the circumstances of his father's death. He asks Horatio to keenly observe the King's reaction during this scene, specifically when the murder is enacted, to confirm the Ghost's accusations.

The court enters for the play. Hamlet engages in banter with the King, Ophelia, and Polonius, making pointed remarks and bawdy jokes, further cultivating his "antic disposition." The play, titled "The Mouse-trap" by Hamlet, begins with a dumb show depicting a King and Queen, the King sleeping, a villain pouring poison in his ear, and the villain then wooing the Queen. The Prologue then enters, followed by the Player King and Queen. The Player Queen declares undying love and vows never to remarry should her husband die. Hamlet interjects, remarking on the Player Queen's excessive protestation and commenting to Ophelia that "woman's love" is brief. The Player King, feeling unwell, falls asleep. The Player Queen exits. Queen Gertrude comments, "The lady doth protest too much, methinks." Hamlet insists the Player Queen will keep her word. The King asks if there is "no offence in't." Hamlet assures him it's "poison in jest" and for those with "free souls."

Lucianus, the Player King's nephew, enters on stage. Hamlet, acting as a "chorus," explains that Lucianus murders the King "i' the garden for his estate," by pouring poison into his ear. As Lucianus performs this act, King Claudius abruptly rises, crying, "Give me some light: away!" The court erupts in confusion, and everyone exits hastily, leaving Hamlet and Horatio alone. Hamlet is ecstatic, declaring "O, good Horatio, I'll take the ghost's word for a thousand pounds." Horatio confirms he "did very well note him."

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern return, stating the King is "marvellous distempered" with anger. They inform Hamlet the Queen wishes to speak with him. Hamlet, still feigning madness, questions Guildenstern about his inability to play a recorder, then chastises both friends, accusing them of trying to "play upon me" as if he were an instrument easier to manipulate than a simple pipe. Polonius enters, also announcing the Queen's summons. Hamlet makes Polonius agree that a cloud looks first like a camel, then a weasel, then a whale, emphasizing his erratic state. Hamlet agrees to go to his mother. Left alone, Hamlet feels a surge of dark resolve, proclaiming, "Now could I drink hot blood, And do such bitter business as the day Would quake to look on." He reminds himself to be "cruel, not unnatural" to his mother, intending to "speak daggers to her, but use none."

**Scene III: The Queen's Chamber.**
Polonius instructs the Queen to be firm with Hamlet, telling him his "pranks have been too broad" and that she has protected him from the King's wrath. Polonius then hides behind an arras to listen. Hamlet enters. A heated exchange ensues between Hamlet and his mother. The Queen accuses Hamlet of offending his father (Claudius). Hamlet retorts that she has offended *his* father (King Hamlet). When she asks if he has forgotten her, he reminds her she is "the queen, your husband's brother's wife; And--would it were not so!--you are my mother." The Queen threatens to send others to speak with him. Hamlet forces her to sit, declaring he will show her "the inmost part of you." The Queen cries for help, fearing murder. Polonius, from behind the arras, also cries for help. Thinking it is the King, Hamlet shouts, "How now! a rat?" and stabs Polonius through the arras, killing him. Hamlet then reveals the body, calling Polonius a "wretched, rash, intruding fool." He confronts his mother, accusing her of a "bloody deed!--almost as bad... As kill a king, and marry with his brother."

Hamlet forces his mother to look at two portraits, one of his father and one of Claudius. He vividly contrasts his noble father with the "mildew'd ear" that is Claudius, condemning her choice to "batten on this moor." He berates her for her "damnèd incest" and "luxury" with Claudius, accusing her of having "black and grainèd spots" on her soul.

The Ghost of King Hamlet appears, visible only to Hamlet. Hamlet, seeing his father, asks if he has come to chide his "tardy son" for neglecting his command for revenge. The Ghost confirms he came "to whet thy almost blunted purpose" and to protect the Queen. The Queen, unable to see the Ghost, believes Hamlet is mad, speaking to "incorporal air." Hamlet desperately tries to make her see it, but she insists she sees nothing and hears only their voices. The Ghost exits. The Queen, convinced Hamlet is insane, attributes his vision to "ecstasy." Hamlet denies his madness, offering to re-word his statements. He urges his mother to confess her sins to Heaven, repent, and avoid Claudius's bed, to "Assume a virtue, if you have it not." The Queen expresses deep remorse. Hamlet tells her to live purer and bids her good night. He expresses regret for killing Polonius and states he will "answer well The death I gave him." He exits, dragging Polonius's body, proclaiming, "I must be cruel, only to be kind: Thus bad begins, and worse remains behind."

**Act IV**

**Scene I: A Room in the Castle.**
The King questions the Queen about Hamlet. She reports that Hamlet, "Mad as the sea and wind," heard a noise behind the arras, cried "A rat, a rat!" and killed "the unseen good old man," Polonius. The King expresses horror, realizing it could have been him. He immediately decides Hamlet must be sent to England and resolves to "countenance and excuse" the deed to the public, as Hamlet is loved by the "distracted multitude." He summons Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, orders them to find Hamlet, retrieve Polonius's body, and bring it to the chapel. Rosencrantz returns shortly, reporting they cannot get Hamlet to reveal the body's location, but Hamlet is now under guard. The King orders Hamlet brought before him.

Hamlet is brought in. The King demands to know where Polonius is. Hamlet mockingly replies that Polonius is "At supper," not eating, but "eaten" by "politick worms." He tells the King to seek Polonius in Heaven, or if not there, to search "i'the other place yourself," or in a month, he will "nose him as you go up the stairs into the lobby." The King then informs Hamlet that for his "especial safety," he must go to England. Hamlet agrees readily, bidding farewell to his "dear mother," and equating the King to his mother by saying "Father and mother is man and wife; man and wife is one flesh; and so, my mother." Hamlet exits for England.

The King, alone, reveals his secret plot: he has sent letters to England, ordering "The present death of Hamlet." He hopes this execution will cure his own anxieties.

**Scene II: A Room in the Castle.**
The Queen refuses to speak with Ophelia, but Horatio convinces her, explaining that Ophelia is distraught and "may strew Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds." Ophelia enters, clearly mad, singing fragmented songs about a lost true love and death ("He is dead and gone"). She distributes imaginary flowers, assigning symbolic meanings: rosemary for remembrance, pansies for thoughts, fennel for flattery, columbines, rue for sorrow (with a pointed comment to the Queen about wearing her rue "with a difference"), and a daisy, lamenting that violets withered when her father died. She sings about a maiden who was deflowered. The King enters and observes her, noting her "conceit upon her father." Ophelia exits, still singing and saying good night. The King orders Horatio to watch over her closely. The King laments that "When sorrows come, they come not single spies, But in battalions!"

Marcellus enters, warning the King that Laertes is leading a riotous rebellion, with the common people proclaiming, "Laertes shall be king!" Laertes, armed and with followers, bursts in, demanding his father from the King. The Queen tries to interpose. Laertes fiercely declares his intent for revenge. The King, reassuring the Queen of his divine protection, asks Laertes the cause of his rebellion. Laertes demands to know how his father died. The King tells him Polonius is dead but insists he is innocent, promising to help Laertes find the true offender and exact revenge.

Ophelia re-enters, fantastically dressed with straws and flowers, singing about her father's burial. Laertes is devastated by his sister's madness, grieving for the loss of her wits. He observes her symbolic distribution of flowers. Ophelia exits, followed by the Queen. The King reiterates his innocence to Laertes and proposes they jointly seek justice. Laertes, still furious over his father's "obscure funeral" and lack of formal rites, vows to question his death. The King promises "where the offence is let the great axe fall."

Bernardo enters with letters from Hamlet, addressed to the King and Queen. The King reads his letter, in which Hamlet announces his unexpected return, "set naked on your kingdom," and his intent to see the King tomorrow to explain his "sudden and more strange return." The King is baffled. Laertes recognizes Hamlet's handwriting and is inflamed with renewed desire for revenge. The King seizes this opportunity and proposes a cunning plan to Laertes:
They will arrange a fencing match between Hamlet and Laertes, leveraging Laertes' renowned skill, previously praised by a Norman gentleman. Hamlet, being "remiss" and unsuspicious, will not inspect the foils. Laertes can then choose "A sword unbated" (unblunted). Laertes eagerly adds to the plan, revealing he has a "mortal" poison from a mountebank, with which he will anoint his sword point, ensuring that even a slight scratch will be fatal to Hamlet. The King further elaborates: during the match, when Hamlet becomes hot and thirsty, he will offer him a poisoned "chalice" to drink from, ensuring Hamlet's death even if the poisoned blade fails.

The Queen enters, delivering tragic news: Ophelia has drowned. She describes Ophelia making garlands of flowers, climbing a willow tree, and falling into the brook when a branch broke. Laertes is overcome with grief, trying to suppress his tears but unable to control his "womanish passion." He exits, filled with a "speech of fire." The King follows, fearing for Laertes' rage now that his grief is compounded.

**Act V**

**Scene I: A Church Yard.**
Two gravediggers (Clowns) debate whether Ophelia, having "wilfully seeks her own salvation" (committed suicide), should be granted a Christian burial. They engage in a comically convoluted legal argument, filled with puns and misinterpretations of terms like "_se offendendo_" and "_crowner's-quest law_." The First Clown asserts that if Ophelia were not a gentlewoman, she would be buried outside of Christian ground, lamenting that "great folks should have countenance in this world to drown or hang themselves, more than their even christian." They riddle about who builds stronger than a mason, shipwright, or carpenter, with the answer being a grave-maker, whose "houses... last till doomsday." The Second Clown exits to fetch liquor.

Hamlet and Horatio enter, observing the First Clown singing cheerfully while digging up bones. Hamlet is struck by the gravedigger's insensitivity. The gravedigger throws up a skull, prompting Hamlet to muse on its former occupant, perhaps a politician or a lawyer, now reduced to dirt. Hamlet questions the gravedigger, who, playing on words, claims the grave is his because he is in it. The gravedigger reveals he has been a sexton for thirty years, since the day King Hamlet defeated Fortinbras, and since "young Hamlet was born," the Hamlet who is now "mad, and sent into England." Hamlet inquires about how long a body lasts before rotting, and the gravedigger identifies a particular skull as Yorick's, the King's jester.

Hamlet takes Yorick's skull, recalling him fondly from his childhood, remembering Yorick's "infinite jest" and "flashes of merriment." He laments the inevitable decay of all life and greatness, musing how even Alexander the Great and Imperial Caesar are reduced to dust that might "stop a bung-hole" or "patch a wall."

A funeral procession enters with Ophelia's corpse, followed by Laertes, the King, Queen, and mourners. Hamlet and Horatio hide. Laertes asks the Priest what further ceremony will be performed. The Priest explains that because her death was "doubtful" (suspected suicide), her "obsequies have been as far enlarg'd As we have warranty," meaning she receives curtailed rites, not a full Christian burial. He states they cannot sing a _requiem_ for her. Laertes, angered by the "churlish priest," declares his sister will be a "ministering angel" while the priest howls in hell.

Hamlet, upon realizing it is Ophelia's burial, reveals himself, crying, "What, the fair Ophelia!" The Queen scatters flowers on the grave, lamenting that she hoped Ophelia would be Hamlet's wife, not buried. Laertes, consumed by grief, leaps into the grave, expressing his immense sorrow and wishing mountains piled upon them. Hamlet steps forward, demanding to know "What is he whose grief Bears such an emphasis?" He then announces, "this is I, Hamlet the Dane." Laertes leaps out of the grave and grapples with Hamlet, cursing him. The King and Queen order them separated. Hamlet proclaims his profound love for Ophelia, asserting, "I lov'd Ophelia: forty thousand brothers Could not... Make up my sum." He challenges Laertes to prove his grief through action. The Queen attributes Hamlet's outburst to madness. Hamlet exits, stating, "Let Hercules himself do what he may, The cat will mew, and dog will have his day." The King sends Horatio to follow Hamlet and reassures Laertes that they will address the matter with a "living monument" for Ophelia and bring their plan against Hamlet to fruition.

**Scene II: Hall in the Castle.**
Hamlet apologizes to Horatio for his behavior towards Laertes at the grave, recognizing Laertes' grief mirrors his own. Osric, a foppish courtier, enters. Hamlet, continuing his "antic disposition," engages Osric in a witty, confusing exchange about the weather. Osric delivers a message from the King: the King has wagered six Barbary horses against six French rapiers and daggers that Hamlet will not exceed Laertes by three hits in a fencing match of twelve passes. The King desires an immediate trial. Hamlet accepts, saying he will try to win for the King, but if not, he will only incur "shame and the odd hits." Osric departs.

Horatio expresses foreboding, fearing Hamlet will lose. Hamlet admits to a "gain-giving" (misgiving) in his heart but dismisses it as "foolery," defying augury and trusting in "a special providence in the fall of a sparrow."

The King, Queen, Laertes, Lords, Ladies, and Attendants enter for the fencing match. The King asks Hamlet to take Laertes' hand. Hamlet sincerely apologizes to Laertes for his "madness," saying he "shot my arrow o'er the house, And hurt my brother." Laertes accepts the apology "in nature," but states he will still proceed with the match for his honor, accepting Hamlet's "offer'd love like love." Foils are presented. Hamlet chooses one, and Laertes finds one too heavy and asks for another. The King reminds Hamlet of the wager.

The King announces that if Hamlet scores the first or second hit, or is even after the third exchange, cannons will fire, and he will drink to Hamlet's health, dropping a "union" (a poisoned pearl) into the cup. He then drinks (or pretends to) and offers the cup to Hamlet. Hamlet defers, saying he will play the first bout, and sets the cup aside.

They begin to fence. Hamlet scores the first hit. Osric confirms, "A hit, a very palpable hit." They continue. Hamlet scores a second hit. Laertes admits, "A touch, a touch, I do confess." The Queen, celebrating Hamlet's success, takes the poisoned cup and drinks to Hamlet's fortune, despite the King's urgent warning, "Gertrude, do not drink." The King, aside, realizes, "It is the poison'd cup; it is too late."

Laertes, seeing Hamlet winning, decides he must act. He wounds Hamlet with his unbated, poisoned rapier. In the ensuing scuffle, they exchange rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes with the now-poisoned blade. The Queen falls back in her chair, declaring, "No, no, the drink, the drink,--O, my dear Hamlet,--The drink, the drink! I am poison'd." She is carried away, dying.

Laertes, mortally wounded, reveals to Hamlet, "It is here, Hamlet: Hamlet, thou art slain; No medicine in the world can do thee good, In thee there is not half an hour's life; The treacherous instrument is in thy hand, Unbated and envenom'd." He confesses that "the foul practice Hath turn'd itself on me" and that "Thy mother's poison'd: I can no more: the king, the king's to blame."

Hamlet, realizing the full treachery, cries, "The point Envenom'd too! Then, venom, to thy work." He stabs King Claudius, calling him "incestuous, murd'rous, damnèd Dane," and forces him to drink from the poisoned cup. The King is mortally wounded and carried away. Laertes, before dying, exchanges forgiveness with Hamlet, stating, "Mine and my father's death come not upon thee, Nor thine on me!" He dies.

Hamlet, feeling death's approach, says, "Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee." He implores Horatio to live and "Report me and my cause aright To the unsatisfied," as his "wounded name" will suffer if his story is untold. Horatio, in despair, tries to drink the remaining poison, declaring, "I am more an antique Roman than a Dane" (referring to suicide). Hamlet wrestles the cup from him, insisting Horatio must live to tell his story. With his final words, Hamlet states, "The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit; The rest is silence." He dies. The play concludes with a Dead March.

   - Both summaries describe Hamlet’s encounter with the ghost, the revelation of Claudius’s crime, and the ghost’s command for revenge. The generated summary includes the ghost’s warning not to harm Gertrude, which is also present in the original.

   - The generated summary provides a detailed account of Hamlet’s feigned madness, Polonius’s theory, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern’s involvement, and the plan to observe Hamlet with Ophelia. The original summary covers these points more succinctly.

6. **The Play-within-a-Play:**

summary_llm:
The plot of "Jane Eyre" unfolds as follows:

**Childhood at Gateshead Hall:**
The story begins with Jane, an orphan living at Gateshead Hall, where she is mistreated by her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and her cousins, Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed. Mrs. Reed excludes Jane from the family, claiming she lacks a "sociable and childlike disposition." John, the eldest cousin, frequently bullies Jane. During one such incident, he throws a book at her, causing her head to bleed. Jane, enraged, calls him a "wicked and cruel boy." Mrs. Reed, alerted by Bessie (the nurse) and Abbot (the lady's-maid), blames Jane and orders her locked in the "red-room," the room where Mr. Reed (Jane's deceased uncle and Mrs. Reed's husband) died.

In the red-room, Jane experiences intense fear, believing the room is haunted by her uncle's spirit. She recalls that Mr. Reed had made his wife promise to raise Jane as her own child before he died. Overwhelmed by terror after seeing a gleam of light, Jane screams and shakes the door. Mrs. Reed and the servants return, and Mrs. Reed, despite Jane's pleas, extends her punishment, then forcibly locks her back in, causing Jane to lose consciousness.

**Lowood Institution:**
Jane awakens in her bed with Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary, and Bessie present. Mr. Lloyd questions her about her health. Later, Jane overhears Bessie and another servant, Sarah, discussing ghost stories and Mrs. Reed's harshness. The next day, Jane remains miserable despite Bessie's unexpected kindness. Mr. Lloyd returns and, after Jane reveals her unhappiness at Gateshead due to her treatment and lack of family, suggests she go to school. Jane, desiring a complete change and escape, expresses a strong wish to attend school. She overhears that Mrs. Reed is eager to be rid of her. Jane also learns details of her parents' death from typhus fever and her mother's disinheritance by her own father (Mr. Reed's father-in-law) for marrying a poor clergyman.

Mr. Brocklehurst, the manager of Lowood Institution, visits Gateshead. Mrs. Reed tells him Jane is deceitful and asks him to keep a strict eye on her at Lowood, ensuring she is kept humble. Mr. Brocklehurst, who strictly adheres to principles of plainness and denial, agrees. After he leaves, Jane confronts Mrs. Reed, declaring her hatred for her and accusing her of deceit and cruelty. Mrs. Reed, momentarily flustered, retreats. Jane feels a fleeting triumph followed by remorse.

Jane leaves Gateshead for Lowood. Upon arrival, she is met by Miss Temple, the kind superintendent, and Miss Miller, an under-teacher. She observes the strict, austere conditions of the charity-school: insufficient clothing, meagre and often inedible food (burnt porridge), and cold dormitories where washing water freezes. She meets Helen Burns, a fellow pupil, who teaches her about endurance and Christian forgiveness, contrasting with Jane's more rebellious nature. Jane witnesses Helen being frequently and cruelly punished by Miss Scatcherd, a teacher, for perceived faults like untidiness, yet Helen bears it patiently.

Mr. Brocklehurst visits Lowood and expresses his extreme disapproval of any indulgence, including clean tuckers and the supplementary bread and cheese Miss Temple provided. He orders all the girls' hair to be cut short, believing natural curls are a sign of vanity. During this visit, Jane accidentally drops her slate, drawing Mr. Brocklehurst's attention. He makes her stand on a stool and publicly denounces her as a liar, citing Mrs. Reed's accusations, and warns the other girls to shun her. Miss Temple, however, quietly reassures Jane. After school, Jane is in despair, but Helen comforts her, asserting that self-approval is paramount. Miss Temple then summons Jane and Helen, allows Jane to tell her side of the story, and promises to write to Mr. Lloyd for corroboration. She also provides them with a generous tea, noting Helen's poor health. A week later, Mr. Lloyd's letter clears Jane's name, and Miss Temple publicly announces it. Jane thrives at Lowood, becoming a diligent student and later a teacher.

However, typhus fever breaks out at Lowood, turning the school into a hospital. Many girls die, including Helen Burns, who succumbs to consumption. Jane spends Helen's last night with her in Miss Temple's room, and Helen dies peacefully in her arms. The epidemic leads to a public inquiry, which exposes the school's unhealthy conditions and Mr. Brocklehurst's neglect. New regulations and improvements are implemented, making Lowood a better institution.

**Thornfield Hall:**
After eight years at Lowood (six as a pupil, two as a teacher), Miss Temple marries and leaves. Jane feels a profound loss and a renewed longing for change and a wider world. She places an advertisement for a governess position. She receives a reply from a Mrs. Fairfax of Thornfield, offering £30 per annum.

Jane travels to Thornfield, a large, old manor house. She meets Mrs. Fairfax, the kind housekeeper, who she initially mistakes for the mistress. She also meets her pupil, Adèle Varens, a young French girl. Jane learns that the house belongs to Mr. Rochester, Adèle's guardian, who travels frequently. Jane often hears a strange, mirthless laugh and murmurs from the third storey, which Mrs. Fairfax attributes to Grace Poole, a servant. Jane also overhears comments suggesting a mystery surrounds Grace Poole and her high wages.

One evening, while walking to post a letter, Jane encounters a horseman who has fallen on ice. She assists him, and he, in turn, helps himself to his horse. She realizes this stern, dark-featured man is Mr. Rochester, the master of Thornfield. He is intrigued by her.

Mr. Rochester returns to Thornfield and invites Jane and Adèle to tea. He is abrupt and challenging but also shows a keen interest in Jane's mind, art (she shows him her imaginative drawings), and honest opinions. He reveals Adèle is the daughter of a French opera-dancer, Céline Varens, with whom he had a past affair, and whom he discovered to be unfaithful and mercenary. He hints at past sorrows and a desire for "re-transformation." Jane, despite her initial resolve to maintain distance, finds herself drawn to him.

One night, Jane is awakened by a "demoniac laugh" and screams, then a struggle from the third storey. She discovers Mr. Rochester's bed curtains on fire and puts out the flames. He insists it was Grace Poole's nightmare and tells Jane to keep silent about the true events. Later, he confesses to Jane that the "lunatic" woman is confined in the third storey, and that Grace Poole is her keeper. Jane suspects Grace Poole is somehow involved in the incident, but Mr. Rochester dismisses her concerns. He expresses deep gratitude to Jane for saving his life and hints at a profound connection between them.

Mr. Rochester leaves for a party at the Leas, where he is expected to court Miss Blanche Ingram, a beautiful, accomplished, but haughty woman. Mrs. Fairfax believes he intends to marry Miss Ingram. Jane, observing Mr. Rochester's attentions to Miss Ingram, experiences a "poignant pleasure" mixed with despair. She believes he is marrying for social reasons rather than love, as Blanche seems superficial and treats Adèle unkindly. Jane, to remind herself of her own plainness and low status, draws contrasting portraits of herself and an imaginary Blanche Ingram.

During the party, a "gipsy" fortune-teller arrives. Blanche Ingram and other ladies consult her, returning vexed and surprised, claiming the gipsy knew their secrets. Jane is then summoned. In the library, the gipsy, who is Mr. Rochester in disguise, questions Jane about her past and feelings, revealing his knowledge of her habits and suspicions about her love for him. He confesses he feigned courtship of Miss Ingram to make Jane jealous and to test her feelings. Jane, shocked and indignant, admits her feelings for him. At this point, Mr. Mason, Bertha's brother, unexpectedly arrives. Mr. Rochester reacts with extreme distress. He sends Jane for wine and tells her to bring Mason to the library, then locks her in with the wounded Mason, instructing her not to speak to him. Jane then discovers Mason has been stabbed and bitten. Mr. Rochester returns with a surgeon, Mr. Carter, and reveals that Bertha, his mad wife, attacked Mason. He administers a "cordial" to Mason and arranges for his discreet departure.

**The Proposal and Revelation:**
After Mason leaves, Mr. Rochester takes Jane to the orchard. He speaks of his miserable past, his forced marriage to Bertha Mason (a Creole from Jamaica, from a family with a history of madness), and his despair. He describes Bertha's violent and depraved nature, which his father and brother concealed from him for her fortune. He confesses his plan to take a new wife (Jane) despite being legally married, believing he is justified due to Bertha's madness and his own suffering. He proposes marriage to Jane, who, despite her profound love, initially struggles with the moral implications of becoming his mistress.

Jane, tormented, declares she cannot marry him while he is already married. She asserts her independence and moral principles, even though it breaks her heart to leave him. He attempts to coerce her, physically and emotionally, but she remains firm, stating she must abide by God's law. In a moment of intense emotional conflict, as Jane is about to yield, she hears a mysterious voice call "Jane! Jane! Jane!" which she recognizes as Mr. Rochester's, though it seems to come from nowhere. Taking this as a divine sign to flee temptation, she resolves to leave.

She departs Thornfield Hall before dawn, leaving her few possessions and money. She travels for two days, eventually ending up destitute at Whitcross, a remote moorland crossroads. She sleeps on the moors, suffering from hunger and cold.

**Moor House:**
Near death from exposure and starvation, Jane sees a light in the distance and makes her way to a small house, Moor House. She begs for shelter and food, but the old housekeeper, Hannah, is suspicious and initially turns her away. However, St. John Rivers, the young clergyman of the house, discovers her and takes her in. She meets his sisters, Diana and Mary, who are kind and compassionate. Jane, wishing to avoid discovery, gives the false name "Jane Elliott."

Jane recovers at Moor House and bonds with Diana and Mary, who are educated and intellectual. St. John, however, is more reserved and ambitious. She learns that the Rivers siblings are also Jane's cousins: their mother was her father's sister. St. John reveals that their uncle, Mr. John Eyre, of Madeira, has died and left his entire fortune of twenty thousand pounds to his other niece, his clergyman brother's orphan daughter—Jane Eyre. Jane, overjoyed by finding family, reveals her true identity and insists on dividing the inheritance equally among the four cousins, despite St. John's initial objections.

Jane accepts a position as schoolmistress for a new village girls' school in Morton, established by St. John, with a small cottage to live in. She works diligently and gains the affection of her pupils. St. John, observing her character, tries to persuade her to become his wife and accompany him to India as a missionary, believing she is suited for the work, but not for love. Jane refuses to marry him, stating she would be a "useful tool" but not a loved wife, and feels it would be a "monstrous martyrdom" to marry without love. She offers to go as his sister and fellow-missionary, but he insists on marriage as the only acceptable arrangement.

St. John persists in his efforts to persuade her, invoking God's will and warning her of spiritual perdition if she refuses. Jane is almost swayed, but at the crucial moment, she again hears Mr. Rochester's voice calling "Jane! Jane! Jane!" in her mind, seemingly from a great distance. This experience confirms her resolve. She tells St. John she must discover what has become of Mr. Rochester.

**Reunion and Conclusion:**
Jane travels back to Thornfield, which she finds in ruins, having been burnt down. At a local inn, she learns from the former butler the full story: Bertha Mason, Mr. Rochester's mad wife, set the fire. Mr. Rochester, while saving the servants, returned to rescue Bertha, but she jumped from the roof and died. In the collapse of the burning house, Mr. Rochester lost an eye and a hand, and the sight of his other eye. He is now blind and crippled, living in seclusion at Ferndean, a remote manor house, attended only by old John and Mary.

Jane immediately goes to Ferndean. She finds Mr. Rochester, changed but still recognizable, blind and despairing. He does not recognize her voice at first, but when she touches him, he realizes it is she. He is overwhelmed with joy and disbelief, thinking she is a vision. Jane reveals her true identity and that she is now wealthy, having inherited five thousand pounds from her uncle John Eyre. She pledges to stay with him, to be his companion, his eyes, and his hands.

Mr. Rochester, initially hesitant and self-pitying due to his injuries, gradually accepts her love and devotion. He confesses his remorse for his past actions and his belief that his suffering was a divine chastisement that humbled him and led to their reunion. He recounts how he cried out for her in his despair, and heard her voice reply, confirming their spiritual connection.

Jane and Mr. Rochester have a quiet wedding. They live happily at Ferndean. Mr. Rochester eventually recovers partial sight in one eye, allowing him to dimly see their first-born son, who inherits his former brilliant eyes. Diana and Mary Rivers marry and visit them regularly. St. John Rivers goes to India as a missionary, remains unmarried, and dedicates his life to God's work, anticipating his own early death and heavenly reward. Jane and Mr. Rochester enjoy ten years of profound love, companionship, and equality, with Jane serving as his vision and support, finding her ultimate happiness with him.

summary_llm:
Here is a detailed plot summary of the provided text, focusing solely on the events and characters within it:

**Part I**

**Chapter One**
The story begins with the arrival of a new student, a country lad named Charles Bovary, in a school class. He is fifteen, taller than his classmates, and wears an unusual, composite cap that elicits laughter. The head-master introduces him to the class-master, Monsieur Roger, who places him in the second class. Charles is initially shy and awkward, struggling to articulate his name, which sounds like "Charbovari," leading to further ridicule from his peers and the master. Despite the teasing, Charles is a conscientious student.

His family background is then revealed. His father, Monsieur Charles Denis Bartolome Bovary, was a retired assistant-surgeon-major who lost his military position due to "conscription scandals." He married a hosier's daughter for her sixty-thousand-franc dowry, which he subsequently squandered through lavish living. His parents had a strained marriage; his father was dissolute and unfaithful, while his mother became bitter, managing their dwindling affairs with silent stoicism. Charles was spoiled by his mother but his father tried to raise him hardily. He received a rudimentary education from the village curate. At twelve, he was sent to school at Rouen. He was an average student, securing one certificate in natural history. After three years, his parents withdrew him to study medicine. He lived in Rouen, but neglected his studies for public-houses, dominoes, and women, failing his first medical examination. His mother concealed this from his father, and Charles eventually passed five years later by rote learning.

He decided to practice medicine in Tostes, where a doctor had recently died. Charles's mother found him a wife: Madame Dubuc, a forty-five-year-old widow of a bailiff, with an income of twelve hundred francs. Despite her unattractiveness, she had many suitors, but Charles's mother skillfully secured the marriage. Charles had hoped for a freer life, but his wife was domineering. She controlled his finances, dictated his social conduct, harassed his patients for payment, and monitored his correspondence and movements. She was hypochondriacal, constantly complaining and demanding his attention, accusing him of neglecting her and loving another, before asking for medicine and more love.

**Chapter Two**
One night, Charles and his wife were awakened by a request for Charles to attend to a broken leg at the Bertaux farm, eighteen miles away. Due to the dark night, his wife insisted he wait for the moonrise and send a stable-boy ahead. At 4 AM, Charles departed, dozing on his horse until he was met by a boy who led him to the prosperous farm of Monsieur Rouault. Monsieur Rouault, a fifty-year-old widower, had broken his leg. His daughter, Emma, managed the household.

Emma, a young woman in a blue merino dress, received Charles. Charles found Monsieur Rouault in bed. The fracture was simple, and Charles competently set the leg. Emma assisted, pricking her fingers while sewing pads for the bandages. Charles noticed her delicate, almond-shaped nails and dark, candid eyes, noting her grace despite her hands not being "beautiful." Monsieur Rouault invited Charles to eat. During the meal, Emma expressed her disdain for country life and her longing for town experiences. Charles was struck by her appearance and elegance. As Charles was leaving, Emma helped him find his whip, and their bodies brushed, causing her to blush.

Instead of returning in three days as promised, Charles returned the next day, and then regularly twice a week, ostensibly to check on the patient. Monsieur Rouault recovered well, enhancing Charles's reputation in the area. Charles found his visits to the Bertaux a delightful exception to his monotonous life, taking extra care with his appearance. Emma always accompanied him to the first step of the stairs when he left.

Charles's wife, Madame Bovary junior (Heloise), became intensely jealous upon learning of Emma's existence and "good education." She accused Charles of preferring "town misses." Charles, weary of her accusations, stopped visiting the Bertaux after Heloise made him swear on a prayer-book. He began to find Heloise unattractive and their domestic life unbearable.

Charles's mother visited, leading to arguments with Heloise about Charles's habits. It was then revealed that Heloise's considerable dowry was largely gone, lost to a notary who had absconded and to mortgages. Charles's father, enraged by this deception, blamed his wife for the unfortunate marriage. Further arguments ensued, and Charles's parents left. A week later, Heloise suffered a hemorrhage and died. Charles was deeply surprised and saddened, reflecting on her love for him.

**Chapter Three**
Old Rouault brought Charles seventy-five francs and a turkey for his medical services, offering condolences for his loss and encouraging him to visit the Bertaux for solace. Charles followed this advice and returned to the farm, finding it lively and unchanged since his last visit five months prior. Rouault, now recovered, treated Charles with great attention due to his widowhood. Charles found himself laughing, then was momentarily depressed by the memory of his deceased wife, but soon forgot her over coffee.

Charles grew accustomed to living alone, finding new delight in his independence. His practice increased due to local sympathy. He was now free to visit the Bertaux as he wished, feeling vaguely happy and even more handsome. One afternoon, he found Emma alone in the dim kitchen, sewing. She offered him a glass of liqueur, and they shared a drink, Emma provocatively licking the bottom of her glass. They conversed, Emma speaking of her convent education and her dislike for country life, revealing her dreams of urbanity.

Returning home, Charles was consumed by thoughts of Emma, wondering if she would marry and to whom. He was sleepless, imagining her. He resolved to propose marriage, but his shyness prevented him from speaking. Old Rouault, eager to marry off Emma and in financial difficulty, observed Charles's blushes and decided he would accept the proposal.

At Michaelmas, Charles spent three days at the Bertaux. On his departure, he finally stammered out a proposal to Rouault, who, after consulting Emma, signaled her acceptance by opening a window shutter. The next day, Emma, blushing, accepted Charles. They agreed to marry in the spring, after Charles's mourning period. Emma began preparing her trousseau, dreaming of a romantic, midnight wedding, but settled for a large, traditional country wedding with forty-three guests, lasting sixteen hours and continuing for days.

**Chapter Four**
The wedding guests arrived from various villages in diverse conveyances. Both families' relatives and friends attended, dressed in their finest, despite the country setting. The gentlemen helped unharness the horses. The wedding procession walked to the mairie and then the church. Emma's long dress trailed, and Charles waited for her. Charles's father, despite despising the country folk, flirted with a young peasant, while Charles's mother walked with old Rouault. The guests talked business or made jokes. The fiddler played continuously.

The wedding feast was held under a cart-shed, featuring an abundance of rich dishes, including sirloins, fricassees, roast suckling pig, and elaborate desserts, notably a confectioner's work representing a temple and castle. Eating continued late into the night, interspersed with games and drunken revelry. Some guests snored at the table. Horses, overfed, became difficult to manage when guests departed, leading to runaway carts. Those who stayed continued drinking. A cousin attempted a prank on Emma, but Rouault stopped him, citing Charles's social standing. Charles's mother, feeling excluded, retired early, while his father drank kirsch-punch all night. Charles, not being witty, did not shine at the wedding reception.

The next day, Charles was transformed, openly affectionate with Emma, calling her "my wife." Two days after the wedding, Charles and Emma left for Tostes. Old Rouault accompanied them part of the way, feeling a deep sadness as he watched their carriage disappear, recalling his own wedding and lost happiness. Charles and Emma arrived at Tostes to be greeted by their old servant, Nastasie, who apologized for the unprepared dinner and invited Emma to inspect their new home.

**Chapter Five**
The Bovarys' house in Tostes is described as a modest, brick-fronted dwelling. It contained a combined dining and sitting room, a small consulting room for Charles filled with medical books, and a dilapidated back room for storage. The garden featured a sundial and a plaster statue of a curate reading his breviary. Upstairs, their bedroom contained a mahogany bed and a shell box. Emma noticed a bride's bouquet on the secretary, which had belonged to Charles's deceased first wife. Charles, observing her gaze, moved the bouquet to the attic. Emma, reflecting on her own bridal flowers, wondered what would become of them if she were to die.

Emma began to make changes to the house, redecorating and arranging the garden, even considering a fountain. Charles, happy and carefree, bought a second-hand dogcart for her. He found endless joy in their domestic life and adored Emma, reproaching himself for not loving her more, even finding beauty in her morning appearance. He was constantly affectionate towards her.

Emma, however, felt a profound disappointment. She had believed herself in love before marriage, but the expected "felicity, passion, rapture" from books had not materialized. She couldn't articulate her vague unhappiness.

**Chapter Six**
Emma's early life is narrated. At thirteen, she was sent to a convent, where she initially enjoyed the religious atmosphere, romanticizing it and inventing sins for confession. She read romantic and historical novels, dreaming of elegant manor-houses, heroic figures, and exotic landscapes, contrasting them with her familiarity with rustic life. When her mother died, she mourned dramatically, seeing herself as a figure of "pale lives." The nuns noticed her growing detachment from religious vocation. Upon leaving the convent, she initially enjoyed managing her father's household, but soon grew bored and missed the convent. When Charles first came to the Bertaux, she felt "disillusioned," believing she had nothing left to learn or feel. However, Charles's presence and the novelty of her new situation made her believe she was finally experiencing the "wondrous passion" she had read about. She now felt that the quiet calm of her life was not the happiness she had truly desired.

**Chapter Seven**
Emma sometimes viewed her honeymoon as the happiest time, yet longed for exotic lands, luxury, and a husband who understood "all mysteries." Charles's conversation was ordinary, and he lacked the worldly accomplishments she admired. He believed her to be happy, which irritated her. Emma's artistic pursuits, like drawing and playing the piano, were admired by Charles, but she felt unfulfilled. She managed their household well, which contributed to Charles's rising self-esteem.

Charles's mother frequently visited, criticizing Emma's extravagant tastes and lack of domestic economy. She saw Charles's love for Emma as a desertion of her own maternal affection. Charles was caught between the two women, unable to resolve their conflicts. Emma, attempting to generate love for Charles, recited passionate verses and melancholic songs, but remained unmoved, and Charles equally so. She concluded that Charles's passion was merely a habit.

She received an Italian greyhound and often walked alone to a deserted pavilion, contemplating her unhappiness. She yearned for a different life, imagining a handsome, witty, distinguished husband and the vibrant city life her former convent companions might have. Her life felt "cold" and filled with "ennui." She recalled her past school triumphs, now distant.

In late September, the Marquis d'Andervilliers, whom Charles had cured, invited them to a ball at his château, Vaubyessard. The Marquis, impressed by Emma's appearance, extended the invitation. Charles and Emma set out for Vaubyessard in their dogcart.

**Chapter Eight**
They arrived at the grand, modern château of Vaubyessard at nightfall, welcomed by servants and the Marquis. Emma was impressed by the opulent marble vestibule, the gallery with ancestral portraits, and the billiard room. She met the Marchioness.

At dinner, Emma observed the refined atmosphere and the elegant guests. She noticed the old Duke de Laverdiere, the Marquis's father-in-law, eating sloppily, and was fascinated by his past as a courtier and lover of Marie Antoinette. She tasted exotic foods and iced champagne for the first time.

The ladies prepared for the ball. Emma meticulously dressed. Charles, his trousers tight, asked if he would dance. Emma forbade him, saying it was more appropriate for a doctor to remain seated. The ball began. Emma, at first nervous, soon gave herself up to the music, watching the elegant dancers. She observed a young woman discreetly pass something white into a gentleman's hat.

After supper, the cotillion began. Emma, who did not know how to waltz, was asked by a Viscount. They danced, and Emma felt a "torpor" and briefly rested her head on his chest. She continued to waltz with him, attracting attention.

After the guests retired, Charles, exhausted, took off his boots. Emma, still awake, opened the window, breathing in the damp night air, trying to prolong the illusion of this luxurious life. She wished to know the lives of the château's inhabitants. She undressed and lay beside a sleeping Charles.

The next morning, after a quick luncheon, the Marquis showed Emma the stables. Charles, meanwhile, arranged for their departure. The Bovarys paid their respects and left for Tostes. On the road, Emma thought she saw the Viscount among some horsemen. They stopped to mend a broken trace, and Charles found a green silk cigar-case, emblazoned, containing two cigars. He put it in his pocket, despite Emma's scorn for his smoking.

Back in Tostes, dinner was not ready. Emma, in a fit of temper, fired their servant, Nastasie. Charles, fond of Nastasie, was unhappy. Charles smoked one of the found cigars, but Emma, disgusted, threw the cigar-case into the cupboard.

The next day, Emma felt a profound emptiness. The visit to Vaubyessard had created a chasm in her life. She meticulously put away her ball gown. The memory of the ball became her sole occupation, a source of longing and regret for a life she felt she was missing.

**Chapter Nine**
Emma frequently retrieved the green silk cigar case from the cupboard, smelling its scent of verbena and tobacco, associating it with the Viscount and her dreams of Paris. She bought a map of Paris and lady's journals, devouring accounts of high society, fashion, and theatre, seeking imaginary fulfillment. The Viscount's image expanded to encompass all her dreams of a grander life. She saw her immediate surroundings and Charles's "mediocrity" as a personal trap, believing true joys and passions existed elsewhere, in luxury and elegance.

The coarse stable-boy contrasted sharply with her romantic ideals. Emma hired a new, young, orphan servant named Félicité, whom she tried to mold into a lady's maid. Félicité secretly stole sugar. Emma often retreated to her room, reading, dreaming of travel, or returning to the convent, wishing to die and live in Paris simultaneously.

Charles, despite his taxing work, found comfort in Emma and the domestic improvements she made, which he saw as "golden dust" on his life. His reputation as a doctor grew. Emma, however, grew increasingly irritated by Charles's lack of ambition, his crude habits, and his general mediocrity. She tried to improve his appearance, but it was for her own "nervous irritation" rather than for him. She confided her thoughts and readings to Charles, who was an "ever-open ear," but she secretly longed for "something to happen," turning her "despairing eyes upon the solitude of her life."

She suffered from dyspnoea and giddiness in spring and hoped for another ball at Vaubyessard, but when it didn't materialize, she fell into a deeper ennui. She abandoned her hobbies. Sundays were particularly mournful. Winter brought cold and intensified her boredom. She wished to speak to the servant but was restrained by shame.

The village life, with its mundane characters and sounds, only highlighted her dissatisfaction. An organ-grinder's music brought her "echoes of the world" beyond Yonville, stirring her melancholy. Meal times with Charles became unbearable. Emma neglected her household duties, prompting criticism from Charles's mother, who visited during Lent. Emma's sharp replies silenced her mother-in-law. Emma became capricious and openly contemptuous of everything.

Old Rouault visited, bringing a turkey, and Emma found his country talk tedious. Emma grew pale, had heart palpitations, and suffered from fainting spells. Charles believed her illness was local and considered moving. Emma, consuming vinegar, lost her appetite. Charles decided to move to Yonville-l’Abbaye. One day, while tidying, Emma pricked her finger on a wire from her old wedding bouquet; she threw it into the fire, watching it burn, symbolizing the destruction of her illusions. In March, the Bovarys moved to Yonville-l’Abbaye, with Emma pregnant.

**Part II**

**Chapter One**
Yonville-l’Abbaye is introduced as a stagnant market-town near Rouen, lacking distinct character despite its potential. Key landmarks include a church with a crowded cemetery (where the gravedigger, Lestiboudois, grew potatoes on unused plots), a Greek-temple-like town hall, and Monsieur Homais' prominent chemist shop. Homais' shop is adorned with red and green jars and numerous advertisements for patent medicines, reflecting his scientific pretensions.

On the evening of the Bovarys' arrival, Madame Lefrancois, the busy landlady of the "Lion d'Or" inn, prepared for market day. Monsieur Homais, the chemist, expressed his self-satisfaction and criticized the inn's old billiard table, advocating for modern improvements. Binet, the punctual tax-collector, arrived for dinner. The Abbe Bournisien, the curate, came to retrieve his umbrella, but Homais, an infidel, criticized the priest's piety and railed against the clergy, advocating for scientific progress. The "Hirondelle" diligence arrived, delayed by Emma's greyhound, which had run off. Emma, angry and blaming Charles, was consoled by Monsieur Lheureux, a draper and fellow passenger, with tales of loyal dogs.

**Chapter Two**
Emma, Félicité (the servant), Lheureux, and a nurse exited the diligence. Charles was asleep. Homais introduced himself, offering his services and homage. Emma, warming her foot by the fire, revealed her skin in the firelight, observed by Léon Dupuis, a notary's clerk bored with Yonville. Léon was delighted to dine with the newcomers.

Homais, concerned about coryza, kept his skull-cap on and began a long, scientific monologue about medicine, hygiene, and the local climate, boasting about his knowledge. Emma, finding him tiresome, turned to Léon, asking about walks. Léon spoke of sunsets and his love for the sea and mountains, evoking a shared sense of romanticism. Homais interrupted, praising Léon's singing. Homais then listed the notable inhabitants of Yonville to Charles and discussed the house Charles was moving into, noting its conveniences. Charles mentioned Emma's preference for reading over gardening. Léon agreed, and they connected over their shared love for literature and the escapism it offered. Emma expressed her dislike for "commonplace heroes." Homais offered his library, boasting of his journalistic connections.

After a long dinner, during which Léon and Emma's conversation deepened their "common sympathy," Félicité left to prepare the new house. The guests departed. Emma, arriving at her new, bare home, reflected that each new dwelling marked a new phase in her life, hoping this one would be better.

**Chapter Three**
The next day, Emma saw Léon on the Place and quickly closed her window. Léon, still excited by their conversation, found Yonville life tiresome, but was considered "well-bred" there. He enjoyed painting, music, and literature. Homais cultivated his friendship due to a past legal reprimand for practicing medicine without a diploma, hoping to prevent Charles from exposing him. Charles, dull and with few patients, worried about their dwindling finances. Emma's pregnancy delighted Charles, who doted on her.
